posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked:
Hello all, given the poll in the recent “why do people hate Limelight” thread, I thought id make a dedicated poll on the topic.

If you are using something more custom/unique or just want to explain why you chose what you did, make shure to talk about it below!

So, what vision system(s) does your team use?

(This applies to all forms of on bot computer vision, not just Apriltags)

PhotonVision Limelight Northstar Other/Custom 0 voters

posts.name: Christopher Coleman
posts.cooked: Used limelight in the past, will be doing a mix of mostly photon with some limelight this year.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Limelight because it is plug and play.  This year we may be forced to switch to photon and accept the added overhead in exchange for lower cost.

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Tbh photon setup is pretty painless if you use a platform they pre-compile for and use CSI or Arducam USB cameras.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: T.Krauter
posts.cooked: We used both PhotonVision and Limelight on the robot this year. Photon was used for April tag detection and pose estimation, while a Limelight 3 was used for note detection and auto-pathing. Both platforms have advantages, and we will probably continue to use both in the future where their advantages align with game tasks.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: We use PhotonVision, from my understanding it is because of cost. Before apriltags we used a custom solution for the retro reflective tape for that reason. Side note for people who spend time in CAD, I would recommend not setting your camera angle to 28.783 deg down, Programing does not like it. Don’t ask how I know…

My team uses PhotonVision because

a) Was cheaper to initially setup compared to a limelight b) We already knew Linux, so setting up PhotonVision wouldn’t be new for us c) We wanted to have something that was a bit more custom for the fun of it

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Stuff like this is why I cad my own mounts.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: Photonvision on limelight hardware. Got great apriltag detections with very little tuning, was super scalable to more cameras. We did use the official limelight software for the object detection pipelines on one of our limelights and that was pretty painless as well, though the lack of a vendordep was a bit odd

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
While cost was one part for us, mainly when LL first came out our adoption into vision was lower priority to even make useful for us during autos.  We try to adopt simple mechanisms that work without vision.  So since we didn’t need a solution as much the cost becomes more substantial.

In the mean time, PV was being developed which bridged the gap between more custom vision low cost options, so it became our default.  And now the differences are a lot closer so less reasons to adopt LL , even if I think the product is really nice and valuable.  Our technical abilities were too low when it had the largest advantages for teams to make good usage of it.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.cooked: We did photon for localization with a rpi4 and ll3, and did object detection with a ll3 + coral (using limelight software) No major gripes for either library. Both take some time and both work reasonably well.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
We never really got into the LimeLight system, it was too pricey for what it is, and we don’t like putting the camera hardware in the line of fire during competitions.  (we smashed several on the 2022 field, even with a 1" guard for the post…)

We ran a custom solution in 2022 (eventually added a SnakeEyes board to it for easy ring light and PoE, the WpiLibPi image) that was similar to LimeLight packaging.  We didn’t really use vision in 23, and went full PhotonVision in 2024.  We like that the compute core can stay buried in the robot, and use USB ArduCam cameras that we can swap when needed (and cameras are smaller to mount).  Also, the flexibility to use any UVC camera makes camera selection awesome.

suggested_topics.title: LimelightLib (a tiny rant)
suggested_topics.excerpt: Just fyi. Not starting a flame war. Just a gripe. Limelights cost $400 dollars. Can we get a vendor dependency instead of a file that we drop into our code with static methods. Feels a bit cheap.…
